content.description: Students perform an experiment using the setup shown in the figure. A sphere with uniform charge distribution on an insulating stand is placed a distance from parallel uncharged conducting plates separated by a fixed distance <math alttext="d" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Points <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>A</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> are labeled.
content.question: The students predict that the closer the sphere gets to the plates, the larger the electric field between points <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. They measure the potential difference <math alttext="delta V sub A B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>V</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>AB</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> between points <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> for several values of <math alttext="L" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></math>, and the results are shown in the graph. Do the results support their prediction, and why or why not?

choices.label: Yes. The distance between the plates is fixed, so the potential difference between points <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is proportional to the electric field. The increasing potential difference with decreasing distance to the sphere indicates an increasing electric field.

Yes. The electric field is given by <math alttext="the fraction, delta V sub A B, over L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>V</mi></mrow><mrow><mtext>AB</mtext></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math>, and this ratio increases for decreasing values of <math alttext="L" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></math>. Therefore, the electric field increases as the sphere gets closer.

No. The electric field depends on the distance between the points. The prediction cannot be confirmed without knowing the numerical value of <math alttext="d" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.
No. The electric field between two plates is uniform. It will not change regardless of the potential difference between the points.
